Literature Review: The visual system of nonhuman primates is adept at reconstructing the dynamic, three-dimensional (3D) world from the ambiguous two-dimensional (2D) retinal images it receives. This process involves a complex interplay of neural mechanisms distributed across the dorsal (where) and ventral (what) pathways. Each pathway contains specialized channels that process different 3D features, such as shape, orientation, motion, and scene structure. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for elucidating the principles of 3D vision and their implications for both basic science and applied technologies. The dorsal pathway, often referred to as the 'where' pathway, is primarily involved in processing spatial information and guiding actions. Studies have shown that neurons in the middle temporal area (MT) are sensitive to motion in depth, which is essential for perceiving the movement of objects in 3D space (Orban et al., 2006). Additionally, the medial superior temporal area (MST) has been implicated in the processing of self-motion and the perception of 3D structure from motion (Saito et al., 1986). These findings highlight the role of the dorsal pathway in integrating motion cues to construct a coherent 3D representation of the environment. In contrast, the ventral pathway, known as the 'what' pathway, is responsible for object recognition and the processing of detailed visual features. Research has demonstrated that the inferotemporal cortex (IT) contains neurons that are selective for specific 3D shapes and orientations (Logothetis & Sheinberg, 1996). These neurons are crucial for recognizing objects from different viewpoints and under varying lighting conditions. Furthermore, the primary visual cortex (V1) and the extrastriate visual cortex (V2) play a foundational role in the early stages of 3D feature extraction, with V1 neurons responding to binocular disparities and V2 neurons integrating these disparities into more complex 3D representations (Cumming & Parker, 1997). Despite the clear division of labor between the dorsal and ventral pathways, recent evidence suggests that the less-studied area V3A may serve as a critical branchpoint from which multiple 3D-fugal processing channels diverge. Area V3A has been shown to contain neurons that are sensitive to both motion and depth, suggesting its involvement in the integration of these cues (Galletti et al., 2003). This area's expansion in humans may have contributed to the development of advanced 3D spatial reasoning skills, which are essential for tasks such as navigation and tool use (Orban et al., 2006). Neurocomputational differences between the channels within the dorsal and ventral pathways impose distinct information-limiting constraints on perception. For instance, the processing of 3D motion in the dorsal pathway is subject to the aperture problem, where the direction of motion can only be accurately determined along the axis of the stimulus (Adelson & Movshon, 1982). Similarly, the ventral pathway's reliance on binocular disparities for depth perception is limited by the range and precision of these disparities (Cumming & Parker, 1997). These constraints highlight the need for a comprehensive understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying 3D vision to develop more accurate models of visual processing. Convergent evidence from both behavioral and neurophysiological studies supports the idea that the visual system employs multiple strategies to overcome these limitations. For example, the integration of monocular and binocular cues, such as texture gradients and shading, can enhance the accuracy of depth perception (Koenderink & van Doorn, 1976). Moreover, the use of higher-level cognitive processes, such as attention and memory, can modulate the processing of 3D information and improve perceptual performance (Wolfe, 1994). Future directions in the study of 3D vision should focus on exploring the transmission of 3D information across brain areas and the interactions between different processing channels. Advanced imaging techniques, such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and electroencephalography (EEG), can provide insights into the spatiotemporal dynamics of 3D processing (Logothetis et al., 2001). Additionally, computational modeling and machine learning approaches can help simulate the neural mechanisms underlying 3D vision and predict the outcomes of various experimental manipulations (Poggio & Koch, 1985). In conclusion, the visual system of nonhuman primates employs a sophisticated network of specialized channels within the dorsal and ventral pathways to reconstruct the 3D world. The expansion of area V3A in humans may have played a crucial role in the evolution of advanced 3D spatial reasoning skills. Future research should aim to uncover the detailed mechanisms of 3D information processing and the interactions between different brain areas to further our understanding of this complex and fascinating aspect of visual perception.
